results.title: South West Tasmania: The Gliders (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Catherine Millar, John Richardson and Kestrel Film Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Australian wilderness series”.
The sheer challenge of remote wilderness is shown in this spectacular program of a group’s arduous trek up Federation Peak with the aim of hang gliding from the top. Young and old take part in the trek and viewers share in the thoughts, inspiration and differing goals of the group.

results.title: Kimberley: Wandjina country
results.creator_credit: David Morgan, John Richardson and Kestrel Film Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Australian wilderness series”.
Part three of a series of six documentaries that examine the wilderness areas of Australia. Belinda Wright and Stanley Breeden are naturalists and photographers who work for the National Geographic Society. As they become fascinated with the “Wandjina” rock paintings, the viewer also gains some insight into the deep, spiritual relationship the Aboriginal people have with the land. A Teacher’s guide accompanies the video.

results.brief_description: A series of six films, each of which illustrates a proverb by looking at the social manoeuvres of young French couples.

results.title: The Back of Beyond
results.creator_credit: Roland Robinson, Janet Heyer, John Heyer and Shell Film Unit
results.brief_description: Heyer’s romantic impression of life in the inland of Australia featuring the Birdsville Track and its postman, Tom Kruse. Highlights the isolation of the people on outback stations and small towns, and the importance in their lives of the postman and the pedal wireless. Notable in the history of documentary for its strong visuals and use of natural speech, and for being the first production of the Shell Film Unit in Australia. Commentary spoken by Kevin Brennan.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Roland Robinson, Janet Heyer, John Heyer and Shell Film Unit

results.title: Pauline at the beach = Pauline a la plage
results.creator_credit: Eric Rohmer, Margaret Menegoz, Les Films Ariane and Les Films du Losange
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Comedies et proverbes”.
Third in Rohmer’s series “Comedies et Proverbes” this gentle comedy of adult sexual mores, has as its motto a saying of Chretien de Troyes “Qui trop parole, il se mesfait” “A wagging tongue bites itself”. Pauline joins her cousin for a holiday by the sea and has her fifteen year old eyes opened to the duplicity, hypocrisy and plain silliness of adult sexual politics. As the eponymous heroine, Amanda Langlet gives a beautifully subdued performance. Winner of Best Director award at the Berlin Film Festival in 1983. French language with English subtitles.

results.title: Kakadu: Land of the Crocodile
results.creator_credit: David Greig, John Richardson and Kestrel Films (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Australian wilderness series”.
Wilderness is increasingly recognised as a scarce and vital commodity worldwide. In this video, Part 2 in a series of 6 documentaries, Val Plumwood, environmental philosopher and writer returns to Kakadu, where she was the victim of a terrible crocodile attack. Set against the steamy, intensely beautiful, backdrop of Kakadu National Park viewers share her thoughts on wilderness and wildlife. Accompanied by a Teacher’s Guide.

results.title: Le Beau mariage = A Good marriage
results.creator_credit: Eric Rohmer, Margaret Menegoz, Les Films du Carrosse and Les Films du Losange
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Comedies et proverbes”.
Eric Rohmer takes a proverb from La Fontaine as his guiding principle in this, the second of his “Comedies et proverbes”. “Can any of us refrain, from building castles in Spain?” - the castles in Spain, in this instance being the dream of an ideal marriage, which the heroine Sabine pursues in the form of the unwilling Edmond, a lawyer introduced to her by her matchmaking friend. An acutely observed portrait of pain and humiliation, made palatable by Rohmer’s deft handling of the lighter as well as the darker side of human frailty. Beatrice Romand won the Best Actress award at the 1981 Venice Film Festival for her portrayal of the paradoxical Sabine.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Eric Rohmer, Margaret Menegoz, Les Films du Carrosse and Les Films du Losange

results.title: Indelible impressions
results.brief_description: A family of women – they share pride and a passion for life; a love for dancing, talking and eating and each woman has left an indelible impression on those of the next generation. In this story Jade shares her memories and thoughts with the newest and youngest member in the family, her niece, and poses the question, “Will the women of our family leave an indelible mark on you just as they did on me?”

results.title: Full moon in Paris = Les Nuits de la pleine lune
results.creator_credit: Eric Rohmer, Margaret Menegoz, Les Films Ariane, Les Films du Losange and Acteurs Auteurs Associes
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Comedies et proverbes”.
He who has two women loses his soul is the cryptic message at the start of this film in Eric Rohmer’s “Comedies et proverbes” cycle. The he of the message is, in this instance, a she - Louise who cannot bear being “loved too much”. And so she plays a game of seduction with her two aspiring lovers, one of whom she loves too, in her own way. And what if they get tired of waiting, of being available? Pascale Ogier won the best actress award at Venice in 1984 for her role as Louise. She is supported by Tcheky Karyo and Fabrice Luchini.

results.title: Just like dad
results.brief_description: Gemma’s dad, an old rocker from way back, is passionate about music and anything and everything that is remotely connected to music. This addiction comes to a head when dad discovers Ebay on the home computer. Searches and purchases; Ebay has taken over his life. Worse still, Ebay the enemy is now growing on Gemma. She is her father’s daughter! Uses stills and animation.
